<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>: The president is <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup> can veto laws before they become effective (subject to parliamentary override), and holds limited <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Powers_of_the_President_of_Singapore" title="Powers of the President of Singapore">discretionary powers</a> of oversight over the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup> The prime minister and Cabinet are responsible for administering and enforcing laws and policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-Law-77">[75]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a>: The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore" title="Parliament of Singapore">Parliament</a> enacts national law, approves budgets, and provides a check on government policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judiciary</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Singapore" title="Supreme Court of Singapore">Supreme Court</a> and <a href="/wiki/State_Courts_of_Singapore" title="State Courts of Singapore">State Courts</a>—whose judges are appointed by the president—adjudicate disputes between people, and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_review" title="Judicial review">interpret laws</a> and overturn those they find unconstitutional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>The president is directly elected by popular vote for a renewable six-year term. Requirements for this position, which were enacted by the PAP government, are extremely stringent, such that only a handful of people qualify for the candidacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-129">[127]</a></sup> These qualifications include that a candidate needs to be a person at least 45 years of age who is no longer a member of a political party, to either have held <a href="/wiki/Public_administration" title="Public administration">public office</a> for at least 3 years in a number of specific public service leadership roles, or to have 3 years experience as chief executive of a fully profitable <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">private sector</a> company with at least S$500 million in <a href="/wiki/Equity_(finance)" title="Equity (finance)">shareholders’ equity</a>, be a resident in Singapore for at least 10 years, not have a criminal record, and more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_129-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-129">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup> Candidates must also "satisfy" the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Elections_Committee" title="Presidential Elections Committee">Presidential Elections Committee</a> (PEC) that he or she is a person of integrity, good character and reputation.
</p><p>The Constitution requires that presidential elections be "<a href="/wiki/Presidential_elections_in_Singapore#Reserved_elections" title="Presidential elections in Singapore">reserved</a>" for a racial community if no one from that ethnic group has been elected to the presidency in the five most recent terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup> Only members of that community may qualify as candidates in a reserved presidential election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2017_Singaporean_presidential_election" title="2017 Singaporean presidential election">2017 presidential election</a>, this combination of stringent requirements and a reserved election that required the candidate to be of the 13% <a href="/wiki/Malay_Singaporeans" title="Malay Singaporeans">Malay ethnic group</a> led to a single person being qualified for the office;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Halimah_Yacob" title="Halimah Yacob">Halimah Yacob</a>, considered part of the Malay community, won in an uncontested election. She also became Singapore's first female president.
</p><p>Members of Parliament (MPs) are elected at least every five years (or sooner in the case of a <a href="/wiki/Snap_election" title="Snap election">snap election</a>). The 14th and <a href="/wiki/14th_Parliament_of_Singapore" title="14th Parliament of Singapore">current Parliament</a> has 103 members; 93 were directly elected from the <a href="/wiki/Constituencies_of_Singapore" title="Constituencies of Singapore">31 constituencies</a>, nine are nonpartisan <a href="/wiki/Nominated_Member_of_Parliament" title="Nominated Member of Parliament">nominated members</a> appointed by the president, and three are <a href="/wiki/Non-constituency_Member_of_Parliament" title="Non-constituency Member of Parliament">non-constituency members</a> from opposition parties who were not elected in the last general election but appointed to the legislature to increase opposition party representation. In <a href="/wiki/Group_representation_constituency" title="Group representation constituency">group representation constituencies</a> (GRCs), political parties assemble teams of candidates (rather than nominate individuals) to contest elections. At least one MP in a GRC must be of an ethnic minority background. All elections are held using <a href="/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting" title="First-past-the-post voting">first-past-the-post voting</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament.gov.sg_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-parliament.gov.sg-135">[133]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party" title="People's Action Party">People's Action Party</a> (PAP) occupies a dominant position in Singaporean politics, having won large parliamentary majorities in every election since <a href="/wiki/Self-governance_of_Singapore" title="Self-governance of Singapore">self-governance</a> was granted in 1959, promulgating limits on <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">assembly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_association" title="Freedom of association">association</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">expression</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">press</a> except for the <a href="/wiki/Speakers%27_Corner,_Singapore" title="Speakers' Corner, Singapore">Speakers' Corner</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-136">[134]</a></sup> Even its candidates who lose elections are often turned to by constituency residents for assistance. The most effective opposition party is the <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Singapore)" title="Workers' Party (Singapore)">Workers' Party</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist2020election_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-Economist2020election-122">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>The judicial system is based on <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">English common law</a>, continuing the legal tradition established during <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British rule</a> and with substantial local differences. <a href="/wiki/Criminal_law_of_Singapore" title="Criminal law of Singapore">Criminal law</a> is based on the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Penal_Code" title="Indian Penal Code">Indian Penal Code</a> originally intended for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British India</a>, and was at the time as a crown colony also adopted by the British colonial authorities in Singapore and remains the basis of the criminal code in the country with a few exceptions, amendments and repeals since it came into force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trial_by_jury" title="Trial by jury">Trial by jury</a> was abolished in 1970.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> Both <a href="/wiki/Judicial_corporal_punishment" title="Judicial corporal punishment">corporal punishment</a> (<a href="/wiki/Caning_in_Singapore" title="Caning in Singapore">caning</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Singapore" title="Capital punishment in Singapore">capital punishment</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Hanging" title="Hanging">hanging</a>) are legal penalties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>The right to freedom of speech and association is guaranteed by <a href="/wiki/Article_14_of_the_Constitution_of_Singapore" title="Article 14 of the Constitution of Singapore">Article 14(1) of the Constitution of Singapore</a>, although there are provisions in the subsequent subsection (2) of the same Article that regulate them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup> The government has attempted to restrict <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> as well as some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_rights" title="Civil rights">civil</a> and political rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup> In 2022, Singapore was ranked 139th out of 180 nations by <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> on the global <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> ranks Singapore as "partly free" in its <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a></i> report,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_136-1"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-136">[134]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> ranks Singapore as a "flawed democracy", the second best rank of four, in its "<a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> which ranks countries by "perceived levels of public sector corruption", Singapore has consistently ranked as one of the least corrupt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup> Singapore's unique combination of a strong, almost authoritarian government with an emphasis on <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">meritocracy</a> and good governance is known as the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_model" title="Singapore model">Singapore model</a>", and is regarded as a key factor behind Singapore's political stability, economic growth, and harmonious social order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thirdworldtofirst_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-thirdworldtofirst-151">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup> In 2021, the <a href="/wiki/World_Justice_Project" title="World Justice Project">World Justice Project</a>'s Rule of Law Index ranked Singapore as 17th overall among the world's 193 countries for adherence to the <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a>. Singapore ranked high on the factors of order and security (#3), absence of corruption (#3), regulatory enforcement (#4), civil justice (#8), and criminal justice (#7), and ranked significantly lower on factors of <a href="/wiki/Open_government" title="Open government">open government</a> (#34), constraints on government powers (#32), and <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_rights" title="Fundamental rights">fundamental rights</a> (#38).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[151]</a></sup> All public gatherings of five or more people require police permits, and protests may legally be held only at the <a href="/wiki/Speakers%27_Corner,_Singapore" title="Speakers' Corner, Singapore">Speakers' Corner</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup> In 2021, six individuals were given warnings by the police after protesting outside the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)" title="Ministry of Education (Singapore)">Ministry of Education</a> headquarters at <a href="/wiki/Buona_Vista" title="Buona Vista">Buona Vista</a>. They were warned as the protest was considered unauthorised having not been held at the Speakers' Corner. The protests were in regards to demanding more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trans_rights" title="Trans rights">trans rights</a> and support such as <a href="/wiki/Gender_dysphoria" title="Gender dysphoria">gender dysphoria</a> in the Singaporean educational system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR2021_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-TR2021-155">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Singapore" title="Foreign relations of Singapore">Foreign relations of Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg/280px-2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg/420px-2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg/560px-2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong" title="Lee Hsien Loong">Lee Hsien Loong</a> at the 2017 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G20_meeting" title="G20 meeting">G20 meeting</a> in Germany. Since 2010, Singapore has often been invited to participate in G20 processes.</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore's stated foreign policy priority is maintaining security in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and surrounding territories. An underlying principle is political and economic stability in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DFAT_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-157">[155]</a></sup> It has diplomatic relations with more than 180 sovereign states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>As one of the five founding members of <a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> Singapore is a strong supporter of the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Free_Trade_Area" title="ASEAN Free Trade Area">ASEAN Free Trade Area</a> (AFTA) and the ASEAN Investment Area (AIA); it is also the host of the APEC Secretariat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup> Singapore maintains membership in other regional organisations, such as <a href="/wiki/Asia%E2%80%93Europe_Meeting" title="Asia–Europe Meeting">Asia–Europe Meeting</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forum_for_East_Asia-Latin_American_Cooperation" title="Forum for East Asia-Latin American Cooperation">Forum for East Asia-Latin American Cooperation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean_Rim_Association" title="Indian Ocean Rim Association">Indian Ocean Rim Association</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DFAT_157-1"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-157">[155]</a></sup> It is also a member of the Non-Aligned Movement,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup> While Singapore is not a formal member of the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, it has been invited to participate in G20 processes in most years since 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup> Singapore is also the location of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Economic_Cooperation_Council" title="Pacific Economic Cooperation Council">Pacific Economic Cooperation Council</a> (PECC) Secretariat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>In general, bilateral relations with other ASEAN members are strong; however, disagreements have arisen,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-166">[164]</a></sup> and relations with neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Malaysia%E2%80%93Singapore_relations" title="Malaysia–Singapore relations">Malaysia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> have sometimes been strained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rocky_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rocky-167">[165]</a></sup> Malaysia and Singapore have clashed over the delivery of <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a> to Singapore,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Disputes_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Disputes-168">[166]</a></sup> and access by the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces" title="Singapore Armed Forces">Singapore Armed Forces</a> to Malaysian airspace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rocky_167-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rocky-167">[165]</a></sup> Border issues exist with Malaysia and Indonesia, and both have banned the sale of marine sand to Singapore over disputes about Singapore's land reclamation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup> Some previous disputes, such as the <a href="/wiki/Pedra_Branca_dispute" title="Pedra Branca dispute">Pedra Branca dispute</a>, have been resolved by the <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> Piracy in the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Malacca" title="Strait of Malacca">Strait of Malacca</a> has been a cause of concern for all three countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Disputes_168-1"><a href="#cite_note-Disputes-168">[166]</a></sup> Close economic ties exist with <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>, and the two share a pegged currency value, through a Currency Interchangeability Agreement between the two countries which makes both <a href="/wiki/Brunei_dollar" title="Brunei dollar">Brunei dollar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singapore_dollar" title="Singapore dollar">Singapore dollar</a> banknotes and coins legal tender in either country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Singapore_relations" title="China–Singapore relations">diplomatic contact with China</a> was made in the 1970s, with full diplomatic relations established in the 1990s. China has been Singapore's largest trading partner since 2013, after surpassing Malaysia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> Singapore and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> share a long-standing close relationship, in particular in defence, the economy, health, and education. Singapore has also increased co-operation with ASEAN members and China to strengthen regional security and fight terrorism, and participated in ASEAN's first joint maritime exercise with China in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup> It has also given support to the US-led coalition to fight terrorism, with bilateral co-operation in counter-terrorism and counter-proliferation initiatives, and joint military exercises.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-166">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Singapore has diplomatic relations with both the United States and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>, and was one of the few countries that have relationships with both countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> in June 2018, it hosted <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2018_North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_summit" title="2018 North Korea–United States summit">a historic summit</a> between US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_State_Affairs_Commission" title="Chairman of the State Affairs Commission">North Korean leader</a> <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a>, the first-ever meeting between the sitting leaders of the two nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> It also hosted the <a href="/wiki/Ma%E2%80%93Xi_meeting" title="Ma–Xi meeting">Ma–Xi meeting</a> in 2015, the first meeting between the political leaders of the two sides of the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Strait" title="Taiwan Strait">Taiwan Strait</a> since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> in 1950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces" title="Singapore Armed Forces">Singapore Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops,_Kiwi_Base,_Bamyan_Province,_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="712" data-file-width="1072" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops%2C_Kiwi_Base%2C_Bamyan_Province%2C_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg/220px-Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops%2C_Kiwi_Base%2C_Bamyan_Province%2C_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops%2C_Kiwi_Base%2C_Bamyan_Province%2C_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg/330px-Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops%2C_Kiwi_Base%2C_Bamyan_Province%2C_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops%2C_Kiwi_Base%2C_Bamyan_Province%2C_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg/440px-Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops%2C_Kiwi_Base%2C_Bamyan_Province%2C_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flag_lowering_by_Singapore_troops,_Kiwi_Base,_Bamyan_Province,_Afghanistan_-_20101027.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 2007, Singaporean troopers were deployed in Afghanistan as part of a multinational coalition.</div></div></div>
<p>The Singaporean military, arguably the most technologically advanced in Southeast Asia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-janes-20100118_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-janes-20100118-185">[183]</a></sup> consists of the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Army" title="Singapore Army">army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Navy" title="Republic of Singapore Navy">navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Air_Force" title="Republic of Singapore Air Force">the air force</a>. It is seen as the guarantor of the country's independence,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup> translating into Singapore culture, involving all citizens in the country's defence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-187">[185]</a></sup> The government spends 4.9% of the country's GDP on the military—high by regional standards<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-janes-20100118_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-janes-20100118-185">[183]</a></sup>—and one out of every four dollars of government spending is spent on defence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>After its independence, Singapore had only two <a href="/wiki/Infantry" title="Infantry">infantry</a> regiments commanded by British officers. Considered too small to provide effective security for the new country, the development of its military forces became a priority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs.uwec_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-cs.uwec-189">[187]</a></sup> In addition, in October 1971, Britain pulled its military out of Singapore, leaving behind only a small British, Australian and New Zealand force as a token military presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup> A great deal of initial support came from <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs.uwec_189-1"><a href="#cite_note-cs.uwec-189">[187]</a></sup> a country unrecognised by Singapore's neighbouring <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic" title="Islamic">Muslim-majority</a> nations of Malaysia and Indonesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israeli Defense Force</a> (IDF) commanders were tasked by the Singapore government to create the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces" title="Singapore Armed Forces">Singapore Armed Forces</a> (SAF) from scratch, and Israeli instructors were brought in to train Singaporean soldiers. Military courses were conducted according to the IDF's format, and Singapore adopted a system of conscription and reserve service based on <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Israel" title="Conscription in Israel">the Israeli</a> model.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs.uwec_189-2"><a href="#cite_note-cs.uwec-189">[187]</a></sup> Singapore still maintains strong security ties with Israel and is one of the biggest buyers of Israeli arms and weapons systems<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> with one recent example being the <a href="/wiki/MATADOR" title="MATADOR">MATADOR</a> anti-tank weapon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>The SAF is being developed to respond to a wide range of issues in both conventional and unconventional warfare. The <a href="/wiki/Defence_Science_and_Technology_Agency" title="Defence Science and Technology Agency">Defence Science and Technology Agency</a> is responsible for procuring resources for the military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mindef18Feb2008_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mindef18Feb2008-196">[194]</a></sup> The geographic restrictions of Singapore mean that the SAF must plan to fully repulse an attack, as they cannot fall back and re-group. The small size of the population has also affected the way the SAF has been designed, with a small active force and a large number of reserves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-187">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Black_Knight_Singapore_1_(12537881585).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3350" data-file-width="5025" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Black_Knight_Singapore_1_%2812537881585%29.jpg/220px-Black_Knight_Singapore_1_%2812537881585%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Black_Knight_Singapore_1_%2812537881585%29.jpg/330px-Black_Knight_Singapore_1_%2812537881585%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Black_Knight_Singapore_1_%2812537881585%29.jpg/440px-Black_Knight_Singapore_1_%2812537881585%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Black_Knight_Singapore_1_(12537881585).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Air_Force" title="Republic of Singapore Air Force">Republic of Singapore Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/RSAF_Black_Knights" title="RSAF Black Knights">Black Knights</a> perform at the Singapore Air Show.</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Singapore" title="Conscription in Singapore">conscription</a> for all able-bodied males at age 18, except those with a criminal record or who can prove that their loss would bring hardship to their families. Males who have yet to complete pre-university education, are awarded the <a href="/wiki/Public_Service_Commission_(Singapore)" title="Public Service Commission (Singapore)">Public Service Commission</a> scholarship, or are pursuing a local medical degree can opt to defer their draft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup> Though not required to perform military service, the number of women in the SAF has been increasing: since 1989 they have been allowed to fill military vocations formerly reserved for men. Before induction into a specific branch of the armed forces, recruits undergo at least 9 weeks of basic military training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-country-data_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-country-data-199">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of the scarcity of open land on the main island, training involving activities such as live firing and <a href="/wiki/Amphibious_warfare" title="Amphibious warfare">amphibious warfare</a> are often carried out on smaller islands, typically barred to civilian access. However, large-scale drills, considered too dangerous to be performed in the country, have been performed in Taiwan since 1975<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-country-data_199-1"><a href="#cite_note-country-data-199">[197]</a></sup> and in about a dozen other countries. In general, military exercises are held with foreign forces once or twice per week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_187-2"><a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-187">[185]</a></sup> Due to airspace and land constraints, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Air_Force" title="Republic of Singapore Air Force">Republic of Singapore Air Force</a> (RSAF) maintains a number of overseas bases in <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">the United States</a>, and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>. The RSAF's 130 Squadron is based in <a href="/wiki/RAAF_Base_Pearce" title="RAAF Base Pearce">RAAF Base Pearce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Australia" title="Western Australia">Western Australia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup> and its <a href="/wiki/126_Squadron,_Republic_of_Singapore_Air_Force" title="126 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force">126 Squadron</a> is based in the <a href="/wiki/Oakey_Army_Aviation_Centre" title="Oakey Army Aviation Centre">Oakey Army Aviation Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queensland" title="Queensland">Queensland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup> The RSAF has one squadron—the 150 Squadron—based in <a href="/wiki/Cazaux_Air_Base" title="Cazaux Air Base">Cazaux Air Base</a> in southern France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> The RSAF's overseas detachments in the United States are: <a href="/wiki/Luke_Air_Force_Base" title="Luke Air Force Base">Luke Air Force Base</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a>), <a href="/wiki/Marana,_Arizona" title="Marana, Arizona">Marana</a> (Arizona), <a href="/wiki/Mountain_Home_Air_Force_Base" title="Mountain Home Air Force Base">Mountain Home Air Force Base</a> (<a href="/wiki/Idaho" title="Idaho">Idaho</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Andersen_Air_Force_Base" title="Andersen Air Force Base">Andersen Air Force Base</a> (<a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>The SAF has sent forces to assist in operations outside the country, in areas such as <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup> in both military and civilian roles. In the region, they have helped to stabilise <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a> and have provided aid to <a href="/wiki/Aceh" title="Aceh">Aceh</a> in Indonesia following the <a href="/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami">2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami</a>. Since 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Navy" title="Republic of Singapore Navy">Republic of Singapore Navy</a> (RSN) has deployed ships to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aden" title="Gulf of Aden">Gulf of Aden</a> to aid in counter <a href="/wiki/Piracy" title="Piracy">piracy</a> efforts as part of <a href="/wiki/Combined_Task_Force_151" title="Combined Task Force 151">Task Force 151</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[208]</a></sup> The SAF also helped in relief efforts during <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan" title="Typhoon Haiyan">Typhoon Haiyan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup> Singapore is part of the <a href="/wiki/Five_Power_Defence_Arrangements" title="Five Power Defence Arrangements">Five Power Defence Arrangements</a>, a military alliance with Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_187-3"><a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-187">[185]</a></sup> In 2022, the nation was placed 9th most peaceful country on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Singapore" title="Human rights in Singapore">Human rights in Singapore</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Singapore" title="Abortion in Singapore">Abortion in Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Singapore" title="Capital punishment in Singapore">Capital punishment in Singapore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Singapore" title="LGBT rights in Singapore">LGBT rights in Singapore</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment" title="Capital punishment">Capital punishment</a> is a legal and enforced penalty in Singapore. The country is <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_by_country" title="Capital punishment by country">one of four</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed world</a> to retain the death penalty, along with <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_for_drug_trafficking" title="Capital punishment for drug trafficking">use against drug trafficking</a> has been a source of contention with various <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organization" title="Non-governmental organization">non-governmental organisations</a>, regarded by some as a <a href="/wiki/Victimless_crime" title="Victimless crime">victimless crime</a>. The government has responded that it has "no doubts" that it is the right policy and that there is "clear evidence" of serious deterrence, and that the law should be looked at upon in the context of "saving lives".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> has said that some legal provisions of the Singapore system for the death penalty conflict with "the right to be <a href="/wiki/Presumption_of_innocence" title="Presumption of innocence">presumed innocent</a> until proven guilty".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-amnesty_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-amnesty-214">[212]</a></sup> The government has disputed Amnesty's claims, stating that their "position on abolition of the death penalty is by no means uncontested internationally" and that the report contains "grave errors of facts and misrepresentations".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-response_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-response-215">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1938 to 2022, sexual relations between men were technically illegal under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Section_377A_of_the_Penal_Code_(Singapore)" title="Section 377A of the Penal Code (Singapore)">Section 377A of the Penal Code</a>, first introduced during British colonial rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> During the last few decades, the law was unenforced and pressure to repeal this law increased as homosexuality became more scientifically understood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> Meanwhile, sexual relations between women had always been legal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup> In 2022, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong" title="Lee Hsien Loong">Lee Hsien Loong</a> announced that Singapore would scrap 377A for good, effectively decriminalising it. Nevertheless, he added that the repeal will not affect the recognition of "traditional familial and societal norms", including how marriage is defined – putting the legalisation of <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a> on the back-burner at least for now, although the possibility of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_unions" title="Civil unions">civil unions</a> was not officially ruled out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup> He added this was a compromise between the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conservative" title="Conservative">conservative</a> (and often religious) and <a href="/wiki/Progressivism" title="Progressivism">progressive</a> elements of Singaporean society to prevent fracturing it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Procuring_(prostitution)" title="Procuring (prostitution)">Pimps</a> often <a href="/wiki/Sex_trafficking_in_Singapore" title="Sex trafficking in Singapore">traffic</a> women from neighbouring countries such as <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> at their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brothels" title="Brothels">brothels</a> as well as rented <a href="/wiki/Apartment" title="Apartment">apartments</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hostels" title="Hostels">hostels</a> for higher profit margins when they get a cut from customers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup> In response, amendments were made to the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Charter" title="Women's Charter">Women's Charter</a> by the government in 2019 to legislate more serious punishments for traffickers, including imprisonment of up to seven years and a fine of S$100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">Abortion</a> has been legal in Singapore since 1969, and it is available on request.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Singapore" title="Geography of Singapore">Geography of Singapore</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation_in_Singapore" title="Land reclamation in Singapore">Land reclamation in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_(English).png"><img alt="Map showing Singapore island and the territories belonging to Singapore and its neighbours" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="350" data-file-width="327" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_%28English%29.png/220px-CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_%28English%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/07/CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_%28English%29.png 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_(English).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An outline of Singapore and the surrounding islands and waterways</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore consists of <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Singapore" title="List of islands of Singapore">63 islands</a>, including the main island, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pulau_Ujong" title="Pulau Ujong">Pulau Ujong</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup> There are two man-made connections to <a href="/wiki/Johor" title="Johor">Johor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway" title="Johor–Singapore Causeway">Johor–Singapore Causeway</a> in the north and the <a href="/wiki/Malaysia%E2%80%93Singapore_Second_Link" title="Malaysia–Singapore Second Link">Tuas Second Link</a> in the west. <a href="/wiki/Jurong_Island" title="Jurong Island">Jurong Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Tekong" title="Pulau Tekong">Pulau Tekong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Ubin" title="Pulau Ubin">Pulau Ubin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sentosa" title="Sentosa">Sentosa</a> are the largest of Singapore's smaller islands. The highest natural point is <a href="/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Hill" title="Bukit Timah Hill">Bukit Timah Hill</a> at 163.63 m (537 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> Under British rule, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_Island" title="Christmas Island">Christmas Island</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Cocos_(Keeling)_Islands" title="Cocos (Keeling) Islands">Cocos Islands</a> were part of Singapore, and both were transferred to <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> in 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pedra_Branca,_Singapore" title="Pedra Branca, Singapore">Pedra Branca</a> is the nation's easternmost point.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBA_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-PBA-230">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">Land reclamation</a> projects have increased Singapore's land area from 580 km<sup>2</sup> (220 sq mi) in the 1960s to 710 km<sup>2</sup> (270 sq mi) by 2015, an increase of some 22% (130 km<sup>2</sup>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sand1_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-sand1-231">[229]</a></sup> The country is projected to reclaim another 56 km<sup>2</sup> (20 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup> Some projects involve merging smaller islands through land reclamation to form larger, more functional and habitable islands, as has been done with Jurong Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earthshots.usgs.gov_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-earthshots.usgs.gov-233">[231]</a></sup> The type of sand used in reclamation is found in rivers and beaches, rather than deserts, and is in great demand worldwide. In 2010 Singapore imported almost 15 million tons of sand for its projects, the demand being such that Indonesia, Malaysia, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> have all restricted or barred the export of sand to Singapore in recent years. As a result, in 2016 Singapore switched to using <a href="/wiki/Polder" title="Polder">polders</a> for reclamation, in which an area is enclosed and then pumped dry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_(15960226189).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1336" data-file-width="2130" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_%2815960226189%29.jpg/220px-Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_%2815960226189%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_%2815960226189%29.jpg/330px-Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_%2815960226189%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_%2815960226189%29.jpg/440px-Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_%2815960226189%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Walk_through_Singapore_Botanic_Gardens-03_(15960226189).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Singapore Botanic Gardens is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> – one of three gardens in the world, and the only tropical garden, to be recognised as such.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature">Nature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Singapore" title="Wildlife of Singapore">Wildlife of Singapore</a></div>
<p>Singapore's urbanisation means that it has lost 95% of its historical forests,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nature-extinctions_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-nature-extinctions-235">[233]</a></sup> and now over half of the naturally occurring <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Singapore" title="Fauna of Singapore">fauna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Singapore" title="Flora of Singapore">flora</a> in Singapore is present in nature reserves, such as the <a href="/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Nature_Reserve" title="Bukit Timah Nature Reserve">Bukit Timah Nature Reserve</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sungei_Buloh_Wetland_Reserve" title="Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve">Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve</a>, which comprise only 0.25% of Singapore's land area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nature-extinctions_235-1"><a href="#cite_note-nature-extinctions-235">[233]</a></sup> In 1967, to combat this decline in natural space, the government introduced the vision of making Singapore a "garden city",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup> aiming to improve quality of life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> Since then, nearly 10% of Singapore's land has been set aside for parks and <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">nature reserves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[236]</a></sup> The government has created <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Green_Plan_2012" title="Singapore Green Plan 2012">plans to preserve the country's remaining wildlife</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup> Singapore's well known gardens include the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Botanic_Gardens" title="Singapore Botanic Gardens">Singapore Botanic Gardens</a>, a 161-year-old tropical garden and Singapore's first <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p>Singapore has a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest_climate" title="Tropical rainforest climate">tropical rainforest climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a>: <i>Af</i>) with no distinctive seasons, uniform temperature and pressure, high humidity, and abundant rainfall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> Temperatures usually range from 23 to 32 °C (73 to 90 °F). While temperature does not vary greatly throughout the year, there is a wetter <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> season from November to February.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>From July to October, there is often <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asian_haze" title="Southeast Asian haze">haze</a> caused by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bush_fire" title="Bush fire">bush fires</a> in neighbouring Indonesia, usually from the island of <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup> Singapore follows the GMT+8 time zone, one hour ahead of the typical zone for its geographical location.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> This causes the sun to rise and set particularly late during February, where the sun rises at 7:15 am and sets around 7:20 pm. During July, the sun sets at around 7:15 pm. The earliest the sun rises and sets is in late October and early November when the sun rises at 6:46 am and sets at 6:50 pm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore recognises that climate change and <a href="/wiki/Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise">rising sea levels</a> in the decades ahead will have major implications for its low-lying coastline. It estimates that the nation will need to spend $100 billion over the course of the next century to address the issue. In its 2020 budget, the government set aside an initial $5 billion towards a Coastline and Flood Protection Fund.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup> Singapore is the first country in Southeast Asia to levy a <a href="/wiki/Carbon_tax" title="Carbon tax">carbon tax</a> on its largest carbon-emitting corporations producing more than 25,000 tons of carbon dioxide per year, at $5 per ton.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>To reduce the country's dependence on fossil fuels, it has ramped up deployment of solar panels on rooftops and vertical surfaces of buildings, and other initiatives like building one of the world's largest floating solar farms at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tengeh_reservoir" title="Tengeh reservoir">Tengeh Reservoir</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tuas" title="Tuas">Tuas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup>
</p>

</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore" title="Economy of Singapore">Economy of Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Airlines,_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_(20786371995).jpg"><img alt="Singapore Airlines celebrated the nation's Golden Jubilee with a flag livery on its Airbus A380" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2590" data-file-width="3877" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Singapore_Airlines%2C_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_%2820786371995%29.jpg/220px-Singapore_Airlines%2C_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_%2820786371995%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Singapore_Airlines%2C_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_%2820786371995%29.jpg/330px-Singapore_Airlines%2C_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_%2820786371995%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Singapore_Airlines%2C_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_%2820786371995%29.jpg/440px-Singapore_Airlines%2C_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_%2820786371995%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Airlines,_Airbus_A380-800_9V-SKI_%2750th_anniversary_of_Singapore%27_NRT_(20786371995).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Singapore_Airlines" title="Singapore Airlines">Singapore Airlines</a>, the country's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a>, celebrated the nation's 2015 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Jubilee" title="Golden Jubilee">Golden Jubilee</a> with a flag <a href="/wiki/Livery" title="Livery">livery</a> on its <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A380" title="Airbus A380">Airbus A380</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore has a highly developed <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>, based historically on extended <a href="/wiki/Entrep%C3%B4t" title="Entrepôt">entrepôt</a> trade. Along with <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, Singapore is one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Asian_Tigers" title="Four Asian Tigers">Four Asian Tigers</a>, and has surpassed its peers in terms of <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">Gross Domestic Product</a> (GDP) per capita. Between 1965 and 1995, growth rates averaged around 6 per cent per annum, transforming the living standards of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Singaporean economy is regarded as free,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup> innovative,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup>
dynamic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup> and business-friendly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> For several years, Singapore has been one of the few<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> countries with an <a href="/wiki/Bond_credit_rating" title="Bond credit rating">AAA credit rating</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Big_Three_(credit_rating_agencies)" title="Big Three (credit rating agencies)">big three</a>, and the only Asian country to achieve this rating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup> Singapore attracts a large amount of foreign investment as a result of its location, skilled workforce, low tax rates, advanced infrastructure and zero-tolerance against corruption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> It is the world's most competitive economy in 2019, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a>'s ranking of 141 countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> with the 2nd <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">highest GDP per capita</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> Roughly 44 percent of the Singaporean workforce is made up of non-Singaporeans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup> Despite market freedom, Singapore's government operations have a significant stake in the economy, contributing 22% of the GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[264]</a></sup> The city is a popular location for conferences and events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>The currency of Singapore is the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_dollar" title="Singapore dollar">Singapore dollar</a> (SGD or S$), issued by the <a href="/wiki/Monetary_Authority_of_Singapore" title="Monetary Authority of Singapore">Monetary Authority of Singapore</a> (MAS).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup> It is interchangeable with the <a href="/wiki/Brunei_dollar" title="Brunei dollar">Brunei dollar</a> at <a href="/wiki/Par_value" title="Par value">par value</a> since 1967.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Currency_History_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-Currency_History-269">[267]</a></sup> MAS manages its <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> by allowing the Singapore dollar <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">exchange rate</a> to rise or fall within an undisclosed trading band. This is different from most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_banks" title="Central banks">central banks</a>, which use <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interest_rates" title="Interest rates">interest rates</a> to manage policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> Singapore has the world's eleventh <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign_exchange_reserves" title="List of countries by foreign exchange reserves">largest foreign reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> and one of the highest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_creditor_nations_by_net_international_investment_position_per_capita" title="List of creditor nations by net international investment position per capita">net international investment position per capita</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore has been identified as a <a href="/wiki/Tax_haven" title="Tax haven">tax haven</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> for the wealthy due to its low tax rates on personal income and tax exemptions on foreign-based income and capital gains. Individuals such as Australian millionaire retailer <a href="/wiki/Brett_Blundy" title="Brett Blundy">Brett Blundy</a> and multi-billionaire Facebook co-founder <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Saverin" title="Eduardo Saverin">Eduardo Saverin</a> are two examples of wealthy individuals who have settled in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup> In 2009, Singapore was removed from the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD) "liste grise" of tax havens,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> and ranked fourth on the <a href="/wiki/Tax_Justice_Network" title="Tax Justice Network">Tax Justice Network</a>'s 2015 <a href="/wiki/Financial_Secrecy_Index" title="Financial Secrecy Index">Financial Secrecy Index</a> of the world's off-shore financial service providers, banking one-eighth of the world's offshore capital, while "providing numerous tax avoidance and evasion opportunities".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FSI_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FSI-277">[275]</a></sup> In August 2016, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Straits_Times" title="The Straits Times">The Straits Times</a></i> reported that Indonesia had decided to create tax havens on two islands near Singapore to bring Indonesian capital back into the tax base.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> In October 2016, the Monetary Authority of Singapore admonished and fined <a href="/wiki/UBS" title="UBS">UBS</a> and <a href="/wiki/DBS_Bank" title="DBS Bank">DBS</a> and withdrew <a class="extiw" href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falcon_Private_Bank" title="de:Falcon Private Bank">Falcon Private Bank</a>'s banking licence for their alleged role in the Malaysian Sovereign Fund scandal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marina_Bay,_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_(35622190292).jpg" title="Panoramic view of the Central Business District"><img alt="" data-file-height="3110" data-file-width="11781" decoding="async" height="264" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Marina_Bay%2C_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_%2835622190292%29.jpg/1000px-Marina_Bay%2C_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_%2835622190292%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Marina_Bay%2C_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_%2835622190292%29.jpg/1500px-Marina_Bay%2C_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_%2835622190292%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Marina_Bay%2C_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_%2835622190292%29.jpg/2000px-Marina_Bay%2C_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_%2835622190292%29.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Marina_Bay,_Financial_District_and_Singapore_River_(35622190292).jpg" title="File:Marina Bay, Financial District and Singapore River (35622190292).jpg"> </a></div>Panoramic view of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Area,_Singapore" title="Central Area, Singapore">Central Business District</a></div></div></div>
<p>Singapore has the world's highest percentage of millionaires, with one out of every six households having at least one million US dollars in disposable wealth. This excludes property, businesses, and luxury goods, which if included would increase the number of millionaires, especially as property in Singapore is among the world's most expensive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> In 2016, Singapore was rated the world's most expensive city for the third consecutive year by the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup> and this remained true in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup> The government provides numerous assistance programmes to the homeless and needy through the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Social_and_Family_Development" title="Ministry of Social and Family Development">Ministry of Social and Family Development</a>, so acute poverty is rare. Some of the programmes include providing between S$400 and S$1000 of financial assistance per month to needy households, providing free medical care at government hospitals, and paying for children's tuition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup> Other benefits include compensation for gym fees to encourage citizens to exercise,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup> up to S$166,000 as a <a href="/wiki/Baby_bonus" title="Baby bonus">baby bonus</a> for each citizen,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> heavily subsidised healthcare, financial aid for the disabled, the provision of reduced-cost laptops for poor students,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> rebates for costs such as public transport<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup> and utility bills, and more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> As of 2018 Singapore's ranking in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> is 9th in the world, with an HDI value of 0.935.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;">
