<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Employment">Employment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Employment_in_Singapore" title="Employment in Singapore">Employment in Singapore</a></div>
<p>Singapore has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_unemployment_rate" title="List of countries by unemployment rate">low unemployment rate</a> for a developed country, with the rate not exceeding 4% from 2005 to 2014, and reaching highs of 3.1% in 2005 and 3% during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_financial_crisis" title="Late-2000s financial crisis">2009 global financial crisis</a>; it fell to 1.8% in the first quarter of 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> Singapore does not have a <a href="/wiki/Minimum_wage" title="Minimum wage">minimum wage</a>, believing that it would lower its competitiveness. It also has one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">highest income inequalities</a> among <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developed_countries" title="Developed countries">developed countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup> Although recognising that foreign workers are crucial to the country's economy, the government has considered placing limits on inflows of these workers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup> as foreign workers make up 80% of the construction industry and up to 50% of the service industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry_sectors">Industry sectors</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Singapore_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/220px-Singapore_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Singapore_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/330px-Singapore_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Singapore_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/440px-Singapore_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Singapore exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore is the world's 3rd-largest <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">foreign exchange</a> centre, 6th-largest <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GFCI_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-GFCI-310">[308]</a></sup> 2nd-largest casino gambling market,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edmontonjournal.com_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-edmontonjournal.com-311">[309]</a></sup> 3rd-largest oil-refining and trading centre, largest oil-rig producer and hub for ship repair services,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup> and largest logistics hub.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup> The economy is diversified, with its top contributors being financial services, manufacturing, and oil-refining. Its main exports are refined petroleum, integrated circuits, and computers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup> which constituted 27% of the country's GDP in 2010. Other significant sectors include electronics, chemicals, mechanical engineering, and biomedical sciences. Singapore was ranked 8th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021, the same as in 2019 and 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> In 2019, there were more than 60 semiconductor companies in Singapore, which together constituted 11% of the global market share. The semiconductor industry alone contributes around 7% of Singapore's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore's largest companies are in the telecommunications, banking, transportation, and manufacturing sectors, many of which started as state-run <a href="/wiki/Statutory_corporation" title="Statutory corporation">statutory corporations</a> and have since been publicly listed on the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Exchange" title="Singapore Exchange">Singapore Exchange</a>. Such companies include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Telecommunications" title="Singapore Telecommunications">Singapore Telecommunications</a> (Singtel), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Technologies_Engineering" title="Singapore Technologies Engineering">Singapore Technologies Engineering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Keppel_Corporation" title="Keppel Corporation">Keppel Corporation</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oversea-Chinese_Banking_Corporation" title="Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation">Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation</a> (OCBC), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Development_Bank_of_Singapore" title="Development Bank of Singapore">Development Bank of Singapore</a> (DBS), and <a href="/wiki/United_Overseas_Bank" title="United Overseas Bank">United Overseas Bank</a> (UOB). In 2011, amidst the global financial crisis, OCBC, DBS and UOB were ranked by <i><a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Businessweek" title="Bloomberg Businessweek">Bloomberg Businessweek</a></i> as the world's 1st, 5th, and 6th strongest banks in the world, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup> It is home to the headquarters of 3 <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500"><i>Fortune</i> Global 500</a> companies, the highest in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup>
</p><p>The nation's best known global companies include <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Airlines" title="Singapore Airlines">Singapore Airlines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Changi_Airport" title="Changi Airport">Changi Airport</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Singapore" title="Port of Singapore">Port of Singapore</a>, all of which are among the most-awarded in their respective fields. Singapore Airlines was ranked as Asia's most-admired company, and the world's 19th most-admired company in 2015 by <i><a href="/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)" title="Fortune (magazine)">Fortune</a></i>’s annual "50 most admired companies in the world" industry surveys. Other awards it has received include the US-based <i><a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a></i>’s Best International Airline award, which it has won for 20 consecutive years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup> Changi Airport connects over 100 airlines to more than 300 cities. The strategic international air hub has more than 480 World's Best Airport awards as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Singapore&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, and is known as the most-awarded airport in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[325]</a></sup> Over ten <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free-trade_agreement" title="Free-trade agreement">free-trade agreements</a> have been signed with other countries and regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_166-2"><a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-166">[164]</a></sup> Singapore is the second-largest foreign investor in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[326]</a></sup> It is the 14th largest exporter and the 15th largest importer in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Singapore" title="Tourism in Singapore">Tourism in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg/220px-Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg/330px-Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg/440px-Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Skyline_2019-10.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Merlion" title="Merlion">Merlion</a>, the official mascot of Singapore</div></div></div>
<p>Tourism is a major industry and contributor to the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore" title="Economy of Singapore">Singaporean economy</a>, attracting 18.5 million international tourists in 2018, more than three times Singapore's total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup> Singapore is the 5th most visited city in the world, and 2nd in the Asia-Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup> In 2019 tourism contributed directly to about 4% of Singapore's GDP,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-STB_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-STB-333">[331]</a></sup> down from 2016, when tourism contributed, directly and indirectly, to around 9.9% of Singapore's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTTCreport2017_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-WTTCreport2017-334">[332]</a></sup> Altogether, the sector generated approximately 8.6% of Singapore's employment in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTTCreport2017_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-WTTCreport2017-334">[332]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4033" data-file-width="6990" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg/220px-Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg/330px-Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg/440px-Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_skyline_at_sunset_viewed_from_Gardens_by_the_Bay_East_-_20120426.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Marina_Bay,_Singapore" title="Marina Bay, Singapore">Marina Bay</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2015, <a href="/wiki/Lonely_Planet" title="Lonely Planet">Lonely Planet</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> listed Singapore as their top and 6th-best world destinations to visit, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup> Well-known landmarks include the <a href="/wiki/Merlion" title="Merlion">Merlion</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[334]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay" title="Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay">Esplanade</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-337">[335]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marina_Bay_Sands" title="Marina Bay Sands">Marina Bay Sands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gardens_by_the_Bay" title="Gardens by the Bay">Gardens by the Bay</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jewel_Changi_Airport" title="Jewel Changi Airport">Jewel Changi Airport</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/CHIJMES" title="CHIJMES">CHIJMES</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_337-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-337">[335]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_Singapore" title="National Gallery Singapore">National Gallery Singapore</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_337-2"><a href="#cite_note-:2-337">[335]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Flyer" title="Singapore Flyer">Singapore Flyer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_337-3"><a href="#cite_note-:2-337">[335]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Orchard_Road" title="Orchard Road">Orchard Road</a> shopping belt,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Orchard_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-Orchard-341">[339]</a></sup> the resort island of <a href="/wiki/Sentosa" title="Sentosa">Sentosa</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Botanic_Gardens" title="Singapore Botanic Gardens">Singapore Botanic Gardens</a>, Singapore's first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Tourism_Board" title="Singapore Tourism Board">Singapore Tourism Board</a> (STB) is the <a href="/wiki/Statutory_boards_of_the_Singapore_Government" title="Statutory boards of the Singapore Government">statutory board</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)" title="Ministry of Trade and Industry (Singapore)">Ministry of Trade and Industry</a> which is tasked with the promotion of the country's tourism industry. In August 2017 the STB and the Economic Development Board (EDB) unveiled a unified brand, Singapore – <a href="/wiki/Passion_Made_Possible" title="Passion Made Possible">Passion Made Possible</a>, to market Singapore internationally for tourism and business purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Orchard_Road" title="Orchard Road">Orchard Road</a> district, which contains multi-storey shopping centres and hotels, can be considered the centre of shopping and tourism in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Orchard_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-Orchard-341">[339]</a></sup> Other popular tourist attractions include the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Zoo" title="Singapore Zoo">Singapore Zoo</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_Wonders" title="River Wonders">River Wonders</a> and <a href="/wiki/Night_Safari,_Singapore" title="Night Safari, Singapore">Night Safari</a>. The Singapore Zoo has embraced the open zoo concept whereby animals are kept in enclosures, separated from visitors by hidden dry or wet moats, instead of caging the animals, and the River Wonders has 300 species of animals, including numerous endangered species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[343]</a></sup> Singapore promotes itself as a <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">medical tourism</a> hub, with about 200,000 foreigners seeking medical care there each year. Singapore medical services aim to serve at least one million foreign patients annually and generate US$3 billion in revenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Singapore" title="Transport in Singapore">Transport in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ERP_in_Singapore.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2075" data-file-width="2647" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/ERP_in_Singapore.jpg/220px-ERP_in_Singapore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/ERP_in_Singapore.jpg/330px-ERP_in_Singapore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/ERP_in_Singapore.jpg/440px-ERP_in_Singapore.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ERP_in_Singapore.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The world's first urban <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congestion_charge" title="Congestion charge">congestion-pricing</a> scheme <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Area_Licensing_Scheme" title="Singapore Area Licensing Scheme">started in the city centre in 1975</a> and was fully automated by <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Road_Pricing" title="Electronic Road Pricing">Electronic Road Pricing</a> in 1998.</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Road_transport_in_Singapore" title="Road transport in Singapore">road system</a> covering 3,356 kilometres (2,085 mi), which includes 161 kilometres (100 mi) <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_Singapore" title="Expressways of Singapore">of expressways</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Area_Licensing_Scheme" title="Singapore Area Licensing Scheme">Singapore Area Licensing Scheme</a>, implemented in 1975, became the world's first <a href="/wiki/Congestion_pricing" title="Congestion pricing">congestion pricing</a> scheme, and included other complementary measures such as stringent car ownership quotas and improvements in mass transit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[348]</a></sup> Upgraded in 1998 and renamed <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Road_Pricing" title="Electronic Road Pricing">Electronic Road Pricing</a> (ERP), the system introduced <a href="/wiki/Electronic_toll_collection" title="Electronic toll collection">electronic toll collection</a>, electronic detection, and video surveillance technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[349]</a></sup> A satellite-based system was due to replace the physical gantries by 2020, but has been delayed until 2026 due to global shortages in the supply of semiconductors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> As Singapore is a small island with a high population density, the number of private cars on the road is restricted with a pre-set car population quota, to curb pollution and congestion. Car buyers must pay for Additional Registration Fees (ARF) duties of either 100%, 140%, 180% or 220% of the vehicle's Open Market Value (OMV), and bid for a Singaporean <a href="/wiki/Certificate_of_Entitlement" title="Certificate of Entitlement">Certificate of Entitlement</a> (COE) (that varies twice a month in supply based on the number of car registrations and de-registrations), which allows the car to be driven on the road for maximum period of 10 years. Car prices are generally significantly higher in Singapore than in other English-speaking countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BloombergBMW_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-BloombergBMW-353">[351]</a></sup> As with most Commonwealth countries, vehicles on the road and people walking on the streets keep to the left (<a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">left-hand traffic</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[352]</a></sup>
</p><p>Common alternatives to private vehicles include bicycles, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Singapore" title="Bus transport in Singapore">bus</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxicab" title="Taxicab">taxis</a> and train (<a href="/wiki/Mass_Rapid_Transit_(Singapore)" title="Mass Rapid Transit (Singapore)">MRT</a> or <a href="/wiki/Light_Rail_Transit_(Singapore)" title="Light Rail Transit (Singapore)">LRT</a>). Two companies run the train transport system—<a href="/wiki/SBS_Transit" title="SBS Transit">SBS Transit</a> and <a href="/wiki/SMRT_Corporation" title="SMRT Corporation">SMRT Corporation</a>. Four companies, Go-Ahead, Tower-Transit, SBS Transit and <a href="/wiki/SMRT_Corporation" title="SMRT Corporation">SMRT Corporation</a> run the public buses under a 'Bus Contracting Model' where operators bid for routes. There are six <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxicabs_of_Singapore" title="Taxicabs of Singapore">taxi companies</a>, who together put out over 28,000 taxis on the road.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> Taxis are a popular form of transport as the fares are relatively affordable when compared to many other developed countries, whilst cars in Singapore are the most expensive to own worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore is a major international <a href="/wiki/Transport_hub" title="Transport hub">transport hub</a> in Asia, serving some of the busiest sea and air trade routes. <a href="/wiki/Changi_Airport" title="Changi Airport">Changi Airport</a> is an aviation centre for Southeast Asia and a stopover on the <a href="/wiki/Kangaroo_Route" title="Kangaroo Route">Kangaroo Route</a> between Sydney and London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup> There are two civilian airports in Singapore, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Changi_Airport" title="Singapore Changi Airport">Singapore Changi Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seletar_Airport" title="Seletar Airport">Seletar Airport</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup> Singapore Changi Airport hosts a network of over 100 airlines connecting Singapore to some 300 cities in about 70 countries and territories worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> It has been rated one of the best international airports by international travel magazines, including being rated as the world's best airport for the first time in 2006 by <a href="/wiki/Skytrax" title="Skytrax">Skytrax</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">national airline</a> is <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Airlines" title="Singapore Airlines">Singapore Airlines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Singapore" title="Port of Singapore">Port of Singapore</a>, managed by port operators <a href="/wiki/PSA_International" title="PSA International">PSA International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jurong_Port" title="Jurong Port">Jurong Port</a>, was the world's second-busiest port in 2019 in terms of shipping tonnage handled, at 2.85 billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gross_ton" title="Gross ton">gross tons</a> (GT), and in terms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Container_(cargo)" title="Container (cargo)">containerised</a> traffic, at 37.2 million <a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">twenty-foot equivalent units</a> (TEUs).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MPA_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-MPA-363">[361]</a></sup> It is also the world's second-busiest, behind Shanghai, in terms of cargo tonnage with 626 million tons handled. In addition, the port is the world's busiest for <a href="/wiki/Transshipment" title="Transshipment">transshipment</a> traffic and the world's biggest ship refuelling centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BTP_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-BTP-364">[362]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway" title="Johor–Singapore Causeway">Johor–Singapore Causeway</a> (connecting Singapore with <a href="/wiki/Johor_Bahru" title="Johor Bahru">Johor Bahru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>) is the <a href="/wiki/Border_checkpoint#Land" title="Border checkpoint">busiest international land border crossing</a> in the world, whereby approximately 350,000 travellers cross the border checkpoints of both <a href="/wiki/Woodlands_Checkpoint" title="Woodlands Checkpoint">Woodlands Checkpoint</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Iskandar_Building" title="Sultan Iskandar Building">Sultan Iskandar Building</a> daily (with an annual total of 128 million travellers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup> Singapore Changi Airport also had the second and third-<a href="/wiki/List_of_busiest_passenger_air_routes#The_world's_busiest_international_air_routes_by_origin-and-destination_passenger_volume_(airport_pairs)" title="List of busiest passenger air routes">busiest international air routes in the world</a>; the Jakarta-Singapore airport pair had 4.8 million passengers carried in 2018, whilst the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur airport pair had 4.5 million passengers carried in 2018, both trailing only behind Hong Kong-Taipei (6.5 million).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fresh_water">Fresh water</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Singapore" title="Water supply and sanitation in Singapore">Water supply and sanitation in Singapore</a></div>
<p>Singapore considers water a national security issue and the government has sought to emphasise conservation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup> Water access is universal and of high quality, though the country is projected to face significant water-stress by 2040.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[366]</a></sup> To circumvent this, the Public Utilities Board has implemented the <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Singapore#Water_sources_and_integrated_management" title="Water supply and sanitation in Singapore">"four national taps"</a> strategy – water imported from neighbouring Malaysia, urban rainwater catchments, reclaimed water (NEWater) and seawater desalination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[367]</a></sup> Singapore's approach does not rely only on physical infrastructure; it also emphasises proper legislation and enforcement, water pricing, public education as well as research and development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Luan_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-Luan-370">[368]</a></sup> Singapore has declared that it will be water self-sufficient by the time its 1961 long-term water supply agreement with Malaysia expires in 2061. However, according to official forecasts, water demand in Singapore is expected to double from 380 to 760 million US gallons (1.4 to 2.8 billion litres; 1.4 to 2.8 million cubic meters) per day between 2010 and 2060. The increase is expected to come primarily from non-domestic water use, which accounted for 55% of water demand in 2010 and is expected to account for 70% of demand in 2060. By that time, water demand is expected to be met by reclaimed water at the tune of 50% and by desalination accounting for 30%, compared to only 20% supplied by internal catchments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore is expanding its recycling system and intends to spend $7.4 billion (Sg$10 billion) in water treatment infrastructure upgrades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> The Ulu Pandan wastewater treatment was specially built to test advanced used water treatment processes before full deployment and won the <i>Water/Wastewater Project of the Year Award</i> at the 2018 Global Water Awards in Paris, France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> Operation started in 2017 and was jointly developed by PUB and the Black &amp; Veatch + AECOM Joint Venture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Singapore" title="Demographics of Singapore">Demographics of Singapore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singaporeans" title="Singaporeans">Singaporeans</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Race_in_Singapore" title="Race in Singapore">Race in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6389" data-file-width="4773" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif/lossy-page1-170px-KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif/lossy-page1-255px-KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif/lossy-page1-340px-KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KITLV_-_103763_-_Chinese_and_Malaysian_women_at_Singapore_-_circa_1890.tif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chinese (<a href="/wiki/East_Asian_people" title="East Asian people">East Asian</a>), Malay (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Southeast_Asia" title="Indigenous peoples of Southeast Asia">Southeast Asian</a>), and Indian (<a href="/wiki/South_Asian_ethnic_groups" title="South Asian ethnic groups">South Asian</a>) women in Singapore, circa 1890. To promote racial harmony among the three races, a unique <a href="/wiki/Racial_Harmony_Day" title="Racial Harmony Day">Racial Harmony Day</a> is celebrated on 21 July every year.</div></div></div>
<p>As of mid-2018, the estimated population of Singapore was 5,638,700 people, 3,471,900 (61.6%) of whom were <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_nationality_law" title="Singaporean nationality law">citizens</a>, while the remaining 2,166,800 (38.4%) were <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residency_in_Singapore" title="Permanent residency in Singapore">permanent residents</a> (522,300) or <a href="/wiki/International_student" title="International student">international students</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_worker" title="Foreign worker">foreign workers</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Dependant" title="Dependant">dependants</a> (1,644,500).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_and_Population_Structure_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-Population_and_Population_Structure-3">[3]</a></sup> According to the country's 2010 census, nearly 23% of Singaporean residents (i.e. citizens and permanent residents) were <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born" title="Foreign born">foreign born</a>; if non-residents were counted, nearly 43% of the total population were foreign born.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010census_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010census-376">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-un.org_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-un.org-377">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>The same census also reports that about 74.1% of residents were of Chinese descent, 13.4% of Malay descent, 9.2% of Indian descent, and 3.3% of other (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurasians_in_Singapore" title="Eurasians in Singapore">Eurasian</a>) descent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010census_376-1"><a href="#cite_note-2010census-376">[374]</a></sup> Prior to 2010, each person could register as a member of only one race, by default that of his or her father, therefore mixed-race persons were solely grouped under their father's race in government censuses. From 2010 onward, people may register using a multi-racial classification, in which they may choose one primary race and one secondary race, but no more than two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>The median age of Singaporean residents was 40.5 in 2017,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat2014respoppro_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-singstat2014respoppro-379">[377]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> is estimated to be 0.80 children per woman in 2014, the lowest in the world and well below the 2.1 needed to replace the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup> The government <a href="/wiki/Population_planning_in_Singapore" title="Population planning in Singapore">has attempted</a> to increase fertility with limited success, as well as adjusting immigration policy to maintain its working-age population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>91% of resident households (i.e. households headed by a Singapore citizen or permanent resident) own the homes they live in, and the average household size is 3.43 persons (which include dependants who are neither citizens nor permanent residents).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat2014h&amp;h_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-singstat2014h&amp;h-384">[382]</a></sup> However, due to scarcity of land, 78.7% of resident households live in <a href="/wiki/Public_housing_in_Singapore" title="Public housing in Singapore">subsidised, high-rise, public housing apartments</a> developed by the <a href="/wiki/Housing_and_Development_Board" title="Housing and Development Board">Housing and Development Board</a> (HDB). Also, 75.9% of resident households live in properties that are equal to, or larger than, a four-room (i.e. three bedrooms plus one living room) HDB flat or in private housing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hdb_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-hdb-386">[384]</a></sup> Live-in foreign <a href="/wiki/Domestic_worker" title="Domestic worker">domestic workers</a> are quite common in Singapore, with about 224,500 foreign domestic workers there, as of December 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[385]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Singapore" title="Religion in Singapore">Religion in Singapore</a></div><p>
Most major religious denominations are present in Singapore, with the Inter-Religious Organisation, Singapore (IRO) recognising 10 major religions in the city state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup> A 2014 analysis by the <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> found Singapore to be the world's most religiously diverse nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup></p><div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
<tbody><tr style="background:#ddd"><th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">Religion in Singapore, 2020<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census2020_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-census2020-1">[1]</a></sup></th></tr>
<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">Religion</td>
<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">Percent</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Buddhism</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:gold; width:31.1%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">31.1%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Singapore" title="Irreligion in Singapore">No religion</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:grey; width:20.0%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">20.0%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Singapore" title="Christianity in Singapore">Christianity</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:purple; width:18.9%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">18.9%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Singapore" title="Islam in Singapore">Islam</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:green; width:15.6%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">15.6%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Taoism_in_Singapore" title="Taoism in Singapore">Taoism and folk religion</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:red; width:8.8%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">8.8%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Singapore" title="Hinduism in Singapore">Hinduism</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:orange; width:5.0%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">5.0%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other religions</td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:blue; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.6%</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Buddhism</a> is the most widely practised religion in Singapore: 31% of the resident population declared themselves adherents at the most recent census. The next-most practised religion is <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Singapore" title="Christianity in Singapore">Christianity</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Singapore" title="Islam in Singapore">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism_in_Singapore" title="Taoism in Singapore">Taoism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Singapore" title="Hinduism in Singapore">Hinduism</a>. 20% of the population did not have a religious affiliation. The proportion of Christians, Taoists, and non-religious people increased between 2000 and 2010 by about 3 percentage points each, while the proportion of Buddhists decreased. Other faiths remained largely stable in their share of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010censuspercentage_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010censuspercentage-390">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are monasteries and <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> centres from all three major traditions of Buddhism in Singapore: <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a>. Most Buddhists in Singapore are Chinese and are of the Mahayana tradition,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup> missionaries having come into the country from China for several decades. However, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thailand's Theravada Buddhism</a> has seen growing popularity among the populace (not only the Chinese) during the past decade. The religion of <a href="/wiki/Soka_Gakkai_International" title="Soka Gakkai International">Soka Gakkai International</a>, a Japanese Buddhist organisation, is practised by many people in Singapore, and mostly by those of Chinese descent. <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a> has also made slow inroads into the country in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Singapore" title="Languages of Singapore">Languages of Singapore</a></div>
<p>Singapore has four official languages: <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Standard_Chinese" title="Standard Chinese">Mandarin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statutes.agc.gov.sg_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-statutes.agc.gov.sg-393">[391]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
<tbody><tr style="background:#ddd"><th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">Language used most frequently at home<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census2020_1-3"><a href="#cite_note-census2020-1">[1]</a></sup></th></tr>
<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">Language</td>
<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">English</td>

<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">48.3%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Mandarin</td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:yellow; width:29.9%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">29.9%</td>
</tr>
<tr>

<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">9.2%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
