</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Tamil</td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:green; width:2.5%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.5%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:grey; width:1.4%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.4%</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
</div>
</div>
<p>English is the <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gupta_244–263_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gupta_244–263-394">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dixon,_L._Quentin_2005_p._625-635_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dixon,_L._Quentin_2005_p._625-635-395">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-396">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TanShermanp340-341_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-TanShermanp340-341-397">[395]</a></sup> and the main language used in business, government, law and education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britishcouncil_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britishcouncil-398">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Singapore" title="Constitution of Singapore">Constitution of Singapore</a> and all government legislation is written in English, and <a href="/wiki/Language_interpretation" title="Language interpretation">interpreters</a> are required if a language other than English is used in the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Singapore" title="Judicial system of Singapore">Singaporean courts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Statutory_corporation" title="Statutory corporation">Statutory corporations</a> conduct their businesses in English, while any official documents written in a non-English official language such as Malay, Mandarin, or Tamil are typically translated into English to be accepted for use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dixon,_L._Quentin_2005_p._625-635_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dixon,_L._Quentin_2005_p._625-635-395">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[401]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a> was designated as a national language by the Singaporean government after independence from Britain in the 1960s to avoid friction with Singapore's Malay-speaking neighbours of Malaysia and Indonesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thirdworldtofirst_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-thirdworldtofirst-151">[149]</a></sup> It has a symbolic, rather than functional purpose.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statutes.agc.gov.sg_393-1"><a href="#cite_note-statutes.agc.gov.sg-393">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> It is used in the national anthem <i><a href="/wiki/Majulah_Singapura" title="Majulah Singapura">Majulah Singapura</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup> in citations of <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_orders_and_decorations" title="Singaporean orders and decorations">Singaporean orders and decorations</a> and in military commands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat1_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-singstat1-408">[406]</a></sup> Singaporean Malay is officially written in the Latin-based <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rumi_script" title="Rumi script">Rumi script</a>, though some Singaporean Malays also learn the Arabic-based <a href="/wiki/Jawi_alphabet" title="Jawi alphabet">Jawi script</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup> Jawi is considered an ethnic script for use on Singaporean identity cards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singaporeans are mostly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bilingual" title="Bilingual">bilingual</a>, typically with English as their common language and their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother-tongue" title="Mother-tongue">mother-tongue</a> as a second language taught in schools, in order to preserve each individual's ethnic identity and values. According to the 2020 census, English was the language most spoken at home, used by 48.3% of the population; Mandarin was next, spoken at home by 29.9%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat1_408-1"><a href="#cite_note-singstat1-408">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-411">[409]</a></sup> Nearly half a million speak other ancestral Southern <a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese" title="Varieties of Chinese">varieties of Chinese</a>, mainly <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">Hokkien</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teochew_dialect" title="Teochew dialect">Teochew</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a>, as their home language, although the use of these is declining in favour of Mandarin or just English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat.gov.sg_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-singstat.gov.sg-412">[410]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Chinese_characters" title="Singapore Chinese characters">Singapore Chinese characters</a> are written using <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese characters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Singapore_English" title="Singapore English">Singaporean English</a> is largely based on <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">British English</a>, owing to the country's status as a former <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore" title="Colony of Singapore">crown colony</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup> However, forms of English spoken in Singapore range from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Standard_English" title="Singapore Standard English">Standard Singapore English</a> to a colloquial form known as <a href="/wiki/Singlish" title="Singlish">Singlish</a>, which is discouraged by the government as it claims it to be a substandard <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English-based_creole_language" title="English-based creole language">English creole</a> that handicaps Singaporeans, presenting an obstacle to learning standard English and rendering the speaker incomprehensible to everyone except to another Singlish speaker.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> Standard Singapore English is fully understandable to all <a href="/wiki/Standard_English" title="Standard English">Standard English</a> speakers, while most English-speaking people do not understand Singlish. An interview with a Singlish speaker shown on English-language television therefore requires translated Standard English subtitles. Nevertheless, Singaporeans have a strong sense of identity and connection to Singlish, whereby the existence of Singlish is recognised as a distinctive cultural marker for many Singaporeans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-417">[415]</a></sup> As such, in recent times, the government has tolerated the <a href="/wiki/Diglossia" title="Diglossia">diglossia</a> of both Singlish and Standard English (only for those who are fluent in both), whilst continuously reinforcing the importance of Standard English amongst those who speak only Singlish (which is not <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">mutually intelligible</a> with the Standard English of other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English-speaking_country" title="English-speaking country">English-speaking countries</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-417">[415]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Singapore" title="Education in Singapore">Education in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Management_University_17,_Aug_06.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG/220px-Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG/330px-Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG/440px-Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Management_University_17,_Aug_06.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Singapore_Management_University" title="Singapore Management University">Singapore Management University</a> is one of six <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Singapore" title="List of universities in Singapore">autonomous universities</a> in the city-state.</div></div></div>
<p>Education for primary, secondary, and tertiary levels is mostly supported by the state. All institutions, private and public, must be registered with the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)" title="Ministry of Education (Singapore)">Ministry of Education</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> English is the language of instruction in all public schools,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup> and all subjects are taught and examined in English except for the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_tongue" title="Mother tongue">mother tongue</a>" language paper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[418]</a></sup> While the term "mother tongue" in general refers to the first language internationally, in Singapore's education system, it is used to refer to the second language, as English is the first language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[420]</a></sup> Students who have been abroad for a while, or who struggle with their "Mother Tongue" language, are allowed to take a simpler syllabus or drop the subject.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>Education takes place in three stages: primary, secondary, and pre-university education. Only the primary level is compulsory. Students begin with six years of primary school, which is made up of a four-year foundation course and a two-year orientation stage. The curriculum is focused on the development of English, the mother tongue, <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Natural_science" title="Natural science">science</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Primary_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-Primary-425">[423]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> Secondary school lasts from four to five years, and is divided between Special, Express, Normal (Academic), and Normal (Technical) streams in each school, depending on a student's ability level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secondary_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-Secondary-427">[425]</a></sup> The basic coursework breakdown is the same as in the primary level, although classes are much more specialised.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[426]</a></sup> Pre-university education takes place over two to three years at senior schools, mostly called <a href="/wiki/Junior_college_(Singapore)" title="Junior college (Singapore)">Junior Colleges</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pre-university_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pre-university-429">[427]</a></sup> As alternatives to Pre-U education, however, courses are offered in other post-secondary education institutions, including 5 polytechnics and the <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Technical_Education" title="Institute of Technical Education">Institutes of Technical Education</a> (ITEs). Singapore has six public universities<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup> of which the <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore" title="National University of Singapore">National University of Singapore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nanyang_Technological_University" title="Nanyang Technological University">Nanyang Technological University</a> are among the top 20 universities in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[429]</a></sup>
</p><p>National examinations are standardised across all schools, with a test taken after each stage. After the first six years of education, students take the <a href="/wiki/Primary_School_Leaving_Examination" title="Primary School Leaving Examination">Primary School Leaving Examination</a> (PSLE),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Primary_425-1"><a href="#cite_note-Primary-425">[423]</a></sup> which determines their placement at secondary school. At the end of the secondary stage, GCE <a href="/wiki/Singapore-Cambridge_GCE_Ordinary_Level" title="Singapore-Cambridge GCE Ordinary Level">O-Level</a> or N-level exams are taken;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[430]</a></sup> at the end of the following pre-university stage, the <a href="/wiki/Singapore-Cambridge_GCE_Advanced_Level" title="Singapore-Cambridge GCE Advanced Level">GCE A-Level</a> exams are taken.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup> Some schools have a degree of freedom in their curriculum and are known as autonomous schools, for <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Singapore" title="Secondary education in Singapore">secondary education</a> level and above.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secondary_427-1"><a href="#cite_note-Secondary-427">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore is also an education hub, with more than 80,000 international students in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[432]</a></sup> 5,000 Malaysian students cross the <a href="/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway" title="Johor–Singapore Causeway">Johor–Singapore Causeway</a> daily to attend schools in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup> In 2009, 20% of all students in Singaporean universities were international students—the maximum cap allowed, a majority from ASEAN, China and India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore students have excelled in many of the world education benchmarks in maths, science and reading. In 2015, both its primary and secondary students rank first in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD's</a> global school performance rankings across 76 countries—described as the most comprehensive map of education standards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[435]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[436]</a></sup> In 2016, Singapore students topped both the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Program_International_Student_Assessment" title="Program International Student Assessment">Program International Student Assessment</a> (PISA)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[440]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Trends_in_International_Mathematics_and_Science_Study" title="Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study">Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study</a> (TIMSS).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup> In the 2016 EF English Proficiency Index taken in 72 countries, Singapore place 6th and has been the only Asian country in the top ten.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Singapore" title="Healthcare in Singapore">Healthcare in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KRW_Facade2_final.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1043" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/KRW_Facade2_final.jpg/220px-KRW_Facade2_final.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/KRW_Facade2_final.jpg/330px-KRW_Facade2_final.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/KRW_Facade2_final.jpg/440px-KRW_Facade2_final.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KRW_Facade2_final.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/National_University_Hospital" title="National University Hospital">National University Hospital</a> is the second largest hospital in the city, serving one million patients yearly.</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore has a generally efficient healthcare system, even though health expenditures are relatively low for developed countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wyatt_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wyatt-450">[448]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organisation</a> ranks Singapore's healthcare system as 6th overall in the world in its <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Report" title="World Health Report">World Health Report</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-WHO-451">[449]</a></sup> Singapore has had the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_infant_mortality_rate" title="List of countries by infant mortality rate">lowest infant mortality rates in the world</a> for the past two decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat2014births&amp;deaths_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-singstat2014births&amp;deaths-452">[450]</a></sup> In 2019, Singaporeans had the longest life expectancy of any country at 84.8 years. Women can expect to live an average of 87.6 years with 75.8 years in good health. The averages are lower for men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup> Singapore is ranked 1st on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Food_Security_Index" title="Global Food Security Index">Global Food Security Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[452]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of December 2011 and January 2013, 8,800 foreigners and 5,400 Singaporeans were respectively diagnosed with HIV,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[453]</a></sup> but there are fewer than 10 annual deaths from HIV per 100,000 people. There is a high level of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immunisation" title="Immunisation">immunisation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup> Adult obesity is below 10%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-457">[455]</a></sup> In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> ranked Singapore as having the best quality of life in Asia and sixth overall in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup>
</p><p>The government's healthcare system is based upon the "3M" framework. This has three components: Medifund, which provides a safety net for those not able to otherwise afford healthcare; <a href="/wiki/Medisave" title="Medisave">Medisave</a>, a compulsory national <a href="/wiki/Medical_savings_account" title="Medical savings account">medical savings account</a> system covering about 85% of the population; and Medishield, a government-funded health insurance program. Public hospitals in Singapore have a considerable autonomy in their management decisions, and notionally compete for patients, but remain in government ownership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[457]</a></sup> A subsidy scheme exists for those on low income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup> In 2008, 32% of healthcare was funded by the government. Healthcare accounts for approximately 3.5% of Singapore's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Singapore" title="Culture of Singapore">Culture of Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3792" data-file-width="2304" decoding="async" height="280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg/170px-Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg/255px-Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg/340px-Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sri_Mariamman_Temple_Singapore_3_amk.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ornate details on top of Sri Mariamman Temple in <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Singapore" title="Chinatown, Singapore">Chinatown</a> district, Singapore's oldest Hindu temple since 1827.</div></div></div>
<p>Despite its small size, Singapore has a diversity of languages, religions, and cultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singapore21_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-singapore21-462">[460]</a></sup> Former prime ministers of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew and Goh Chok Tong, have stated that Singapore does not fit the traditional description of a nation, calling it a society–in–transition, pointing out the fact that Singaporeans do not all speak the same language, share the same religion, or have the same customs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singapore21_462-1"><a href="#cite_note-singapore21-462">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> Singaporeans who speak English as their native language would likely lean toward <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a> (along with either <a href="/wiki/Christian_culture" title="Christian culture">Christian culture</a> or <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[462]</a></sup> while those who speak Chinese as their native language mostly lean toward <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a>, which has linkages with <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">Chinese folk religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism_in_Singapore" title="Taoism in Singapore">Taoism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>. Malay–speaking Singaporeans mostly lean toward <a href="/wiki/Malays_(ethnic_group)#Culture" title="Malays (ethnic group)">Malay culture</a>, which itself is closely linked to <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup> Tamil–speaking Singaporeans mostly lean toward <a href="/wiki/Tamil_culture" title="Tamil culture">Tamil culture</a>, which itself is mostly linked to <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindu culture</a>. Racial and religious harmony is regarded as a crucial part of Singapore's success, and played a part in building a Singaporean identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[466]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Singapore became independent from the United Kingdom in 1963, most Singaporean citizens were transient <a href="/wiki/Migrant_worker" title="Migrant worker">migrant labourers</a> who had no intention of staying permanently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-469">[467]</a></sup> There was also a sizeable minority of middle–class, locally born people—known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peranakan" title="Peranakan">Peranakans</a> or Baba–Nyonya—descendants of 15th- and 16th-century Chinese immigrants. With the exception of the Peranakans who pledged their loyalties to Singapore, most of the labourers' loyalties lay with their respective homelands of <a href="/wiki/British_Malaya" title="British Malaya">Malaya</a>, China and India. After independence, the government began a deliberate process of crafting a uniquely Singaporean identity and culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_469-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-469">[467]</a></sup> Singapore has a reputation as a <a href="/wiki/Nanny_state" title="Nanny state">nanny state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup> The government also places a heavy emphasis on <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">meritocracy</a>, where one is judged based on one's ability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[470]</a></sup>
</p><p>The national flower of Singapore is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hybrid_plant" title="Hybrid plant">hybrid</a> <a href="/wiki/Orchid" title="Orchid">orchid</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vanda_%27Miss_Joaquim%27" title="Vanda 'Miss Joaquim'">Vanda 'Miss Joaquim'</a>, named in memory of a Singapore–born Armenian woman, who crossbred the flower in her garden at <a href="/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar" title="Tanjong Pagar">Tanjong Pagar</a> in 1893.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[471]</a></sup>
Singapore is known as the <i>Lion City</i> and many national symbols such as the <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Singapore" title="Coat of arms of Singapore">coat of arms</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Lion_head_symbol_of_Singapore" title="Lion head symbol of Singapore">lion head symbol</a> make use of a lion. Major religious festivals are <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Singapore" title="Public holidays in Singapore">public holidays</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[472]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_Singapore" title="Dance in Singapore">Dance in Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_literature" title="Singaporean literature">Singaporean literature</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Singapore" title="Music of Singapore">Music of Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Gallery_2_(31322988764).jpg"><img alt="The National Gallery Singapore oversees the world's largest public collection of Southeast Asian and Singapore art" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3056" data-file-width="4127" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/National_Gallery_2_%2831322988764%29.jpg/220px-National_Gallery_2_%2831322988764%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/National_Gallery_2_%2831322988764%29.jpg/330px-National_Gallery_2_%2831322988764%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/National_Gallery_2_%2831322988764%29.jpg/440px-National_Gallery_2_%2831322988764%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Gallery_2_(31322988764).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_Singapore" title="National Gallery Singapore">National Gallery Singapore</a> oversees the world's largest public collection of Singapore and Southeast Asian art.</div></div></div>
<p>During the 1990s the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Arts_Council_(Singapore)" title="National Arts Council (Singapore)">National Arts Council</a> was created to spearhead the development of performing arts, along with visual and literary art forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[473]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_Singapore" title="National Gallery Singapore">National Gallery Singapore</a> is the nation's flagship museum with some 8,000 works from Singaporean and other Southeast Asian artists. The <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Art_Museum" title="Singapore Art Museum">Singapore Art Museum</a> focuses on contemporary art. The <a href="/wiki/Red_Dot" title="Red Dot">Red Dot</a> Design Museum celebrates exceptional art and design of objects for everyday life, hosting more than 1,000 items from 50 countries. The lotus-shaped <a href="/wiki/ArtScience_Museum" title="ArtScience Museum">ArtScience Museum</a> hosts touring exhibitions that combine art with the sciences. Other major museums include the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Civilisations_Museum" title="Asian Civilisations Museum">Asian Civilisations Museum</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Peranakan_Museum" title="Peranakan Museum">Peranakan Museum</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Arts_House" title="The Arts House">The Arts House</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[474]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay" title="Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay">The Esplanade</a> is Singapore's largest performing arts centre. In 2016 alone, it was the site of 5,900 free art and culture events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNA1_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNA1-478">[476]</a></sup>
</p><p>Literature of Singapore, or "SingLit", comprises a collection of literary works by Singaporeans written chiefly in the country's four official languages: English, Malay, Mandarin, and Tamil. Singapore is increasingly regarded as having four sub-literatures instead of one. Many significant works have been translated and showcased in publications such as the literary journal <i>Singa</i>, published in the 1980s and 1990s with editors including <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Thumboo" title="Edwin Thumboo">Edwin Thumboo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Koh_Buck_Song" title="Koh Buck Song">Koh Buck Song</a>, as well as in multilingual anthologies such as <i>Rhythms: A Singaporean Millennial Anthology Of Poetry</i> (2000), in which the poems were all translated three times each. A number of Singaporean writers such as <a href="/wiki/Tan_Swie_Hian" title="Tan Swie Hian">Tan Swie Hian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kuo_Pao_Kun" title="Kuo Pao Kun">Kuo Pao Kun</a> have contributed work in more than one language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[478]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore has a diverse music culture that ranges from pop and rock, to folk and classical. Western classical music plays a significant role in the cultural life in Singapore, with the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Singapore Symphony Orchestra">Singapore Symphony Orchestra</a> (SSO) instituted in 1979. Other notable western orchestras in Singapore include <a href="/wiki/Singapore_National_Youth_Orchestra" title="Singapore National Youth Orchestra">Singapore National Youth Orchestra</a> which is funded by the Ministry of Education<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[479]</a></sup> and the community-based <a href="/wiki/Braddell_Heights_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Braddell Heights Symphony Orchestra">Braddell Heights Symphony Orchestra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[480]</a></sup> Many orchestras and ensembles are also found in secondary schools and junior colleges. Various communities have their own distinct ethnic musical traditions: Chinese, Malays, Indians, and Eurasians. With their traditional forms of music and various modern musical styles, the fusion of different forms account for the musical diversity in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-garland_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-garland-483">[481]</a></sup> The nation's lively urban musical scene has made it a centre for international performances and festivals in the region. Some of Singapore's best known pop singers include <a href="/wiki/Stefanie_Sun" title="Stefanie Sun">Stefanie Sun</a>, <a href="/wiki/JJ_Lin" title="JJ Lin">JJ Lin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liang_Wern_Fook" title="Liang Wern Fook">Liang Wern Fook</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taufik_Batisah" title="Taufik Batisah">Taufik Batisah</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dick_Lee" title="Dick Lee">Dick Lee</a>, who is famous for composing National Day theme songs, including <i>Home</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pink_Dot_SG" title="Pink Dot SG">Pink Dot SG</a>, an event held in support of the <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> community, has drawn thousands of people annually since 2009 with increasing attendance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[484]</a></sup> According to a survey conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Policy_Studies_(Singapore)" title="Institute of Policy Studies (Singapore)">Institute of Policy Studies</a> in 2019, Singaporean society has become more <a href="/wiki/Liberalism" title="Liberalism">liberal</a> on LGBT rights. In the survey, more than 20% of people said that sexual relations between adults of the same sex were not wrong at all or not wrong most of the time, up from 10% in 2013. The survey found that 27% felt the same way about same-sex marriage (an increase from 15% in 2013) and 30% did so about same-sex couples adopting a child (an increase from 24% in 2013).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[486]</a></sup> In 2021, 6 Singaporeans protested for improved <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trans_rights" title="Trans rights">trans</a> protections in the educational system outside the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)" title="Ministry of Education (Singapore)">Ministry of Education</a> headquarters at <a href="/wiki/Buona_Vista" title="Buona Vista">Buona Vista</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR2021_155-1"><a href="#cite_note-TR2021-155">[153]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine" title="Singaporean cuisine">Singaporean cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market,_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg"><img alt="Satay stalls along Boon Tat Street next to Telok Ayer Market, better known as Lau Pa Sat" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg/220px-Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg/330px-Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg/440px-Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market,_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lau_Pa_Sat" title="Lau Pa Sat">Lau Pa Sat</a> hawker centre in the financial district. <a href="/wiki/Satay" title="Satay">Satay</a> cart-stalls roll in after dusk, on a side street.</div></div></div>
<p>Singapore's diversity of cuisine is touted as a reason to visit the country, due to its combination of convenience, variety, quality, and price.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foodways_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foodways-489">[487]</a></sup> Local food items generally relate to a particular ethnicity – Chinese, Malay and Indian; but the diversity of cuisine has increased further by the hybridisation of different styles (e.g., the <a href="/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine" title="Peranakan cuisine">Peranakan cuisine</a>, a mix of Chinese and Malay cuisine). In hawker centres, cultural diffusion is exemplified by traditionally Malay hawker stalls also selling Tamil food. Chinese stalls may introduce Malay ingredients, cooking techniques, or entire dishes into their range of catering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foodways_489-1"><a href="#cite_note-Foodways-489">[487]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hainanese_chicken_rice" title="Hainanese chicken rice">Hainanese chicken rice</a>, based on the Hainanese dish <a href="/wiki/Wenchang_chicken" title="Wenchang chicken">Wenchang chicken</a>, is considered Singapore's national dish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-farleyBBC6nov2015_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-farleyBBC6nov2015-490">[488]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lingCNN14apr2010_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-lingCNN14apr2010-491">[489]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city-state has a burgeoning food scene ranging from hawker centres (open-air), food courts (air-conditioned), coffee shops (open-air with up to a dozen hawker stalls), cafes, fast food, simple kitchens, casual, celebrity and high-end restaurants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-streetfood_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-streetfood-492">[490]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cloud_kitchen" title="Cloud kitchen">Cloud kitchens</a> and food delivery are also on the rise, with 70% of residents ordering from delivery apps at least once a month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[491]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[492]</a></sup> Many international <a href="/wiki/Celebrity_chef" title="Celebrity chef">celebrity chef</a> restaurants are located within the <a href="/wiki/Integrated_resort" title="Integrated resort">integrated resorts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[493]</a></sup> Religious dietary strictures exist (Muslims do not eat pork and Hindus do not eat beef), and there is also a significant group of vegetarians. The <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Food_Festival" title="Singapore Food Festival">Singapore Food Festival</a> which celebrates Singapore's cuisine is held annually in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SFF_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-SFF-496">[494]</a></sup>
</p><p>Prior to the 1980s, <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a> was sold mainly by immigrants from China, India, and Malaysia to other immigrants seeking a familiar taste. In Singapore, street food has long been associated with <a href="/wiki/Hawker_centre" title="Hawker centre">hawker centres</a> with communal seating areas. Typically, these centres have a few dozen to hundreds of food stalls, with each specialising in one or more related dishes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fodor_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-fodor-497">[495]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-streetfood_492-1"><a href="#cite_note-streetfood-492">[490]</a></sup> While street food can be found in many countries, the variety and reach of centralised hawker centres that serve heritage street food in Singapore is unique.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hawker2007_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hawker2007-498">[496]</a></sup> In 2018, there were 114 hawker centres spread across the city centre and heartland housing estates. They are maintained by the <a href="/wiki/National_Environment_Agency" title="National Environment Agency">National Environment Agency</a>, which also grades each food stall for hygiene. The largest hawker centre is located on the second floor of Chinatown Complex, and contains over 200 stalls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hawker2007_498-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hawker2007-498">[496]</a></sup> The complex is also home to the cheapest Michelin-starred meal in the world – a plate of soya-sauce chicken rice or noodles for S$2 (US$1.50). Two street food stalls in the city are the first in the world to be awarded a Michelin star, obtaining a single star each.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[497]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport_and_recreation">Sport and recreation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Singapore" title="Sport in Singapore">Sport in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1232" data-file-width="912" decoding="async" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg/170px-Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg/255px-Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg/340px-Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Schooling_Kazan_2015.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Joseph_Schooling" title="Joseph Schooling">Joseph Schooling</a> is a gold medalist and Olympic record holder at the <a href="/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_100_metre_butterfly" title="Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre butterfly">Rio 2016 Games – 100 m butterfly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schooling-Rio_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schooling-Rio-500">[498]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The development of private sports and recreation clubs began in the 19th century colonial Singapore, with clubs founded during this time including the Cricket Club, the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Recreation_Club" title="Singapore Recreation Club">Singapore Recreation Club</a>, the Singapore Swimming Club, and the Hollandse Club.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup> Weightlifter <a href="/wiki/Tan_Howe_Liang" title="Tan Howe Liang">Tan Howe Liang</a> was Singapore's first Olympic medalist, winning a silver at the <a href="/wiki/1960_Summer_Olympics" title="1960 Summer Olympics">1960 Rome Games</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[500]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indoor and water sports are some of the most popular sports in Singapore. At the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016_Rio_Olympics" title="2016 Rio Olympics">2016 Rio Olympics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Schooling" title="Joseph Schooling">Joseph Schooling</a> won Singapore's first Olympic gold medal, claiming the <a href="/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_100_metre_butterfly" title="Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre butterfly">100-metre butterfly</a> in a new Olympic record time of 50.39 seconds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schooling-Rio_500-1"><a href="#cite_note-Schooling-Rio-500">[498]</a></sup> Singapore sailors have had success on the international stage, with their <a href="/wiki/Optimist_(dinghy)" title="Optimist (dinghy)">Optimist</a> team being considered among the best in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup> Despite its size, the country has dominated swim meets in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia_Games" title="Southeast Asia Games">Southeast Asia Games</a>. Its men's water polo team won the SEA Games gold medal for the 27th time in 2017, continuing Singapore sport's longest winning streak.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup> Singapore hosted the inaugural <a href="/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2010 Summer Youth Olympics">2010 Summer Youth Olympics</a>, in which 3,600 athletes from 204 nations competed in 26 sports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singapore_to_host_first_edition_of_the_Youth_Olympic_Games_in_2010_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-Singapore_to_host_first_edition_of_the_Youth_Olympic_Games_in_2010-506">[504]</a></sup> The island is home to <a href="/wiki/ONE_Championship" title="ONE Championship">ONE Championship</a>, the biggest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mixed_Martial_Arts" title="Mixed Martial Arts">Mixed Martial Arts</a> promotion in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup> Singapore's women's table tennis team were silver medalists at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Beijing_Olympics" title="2008 Beijing Olympics">2008 Beijing Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup> They became world champions in 2010 when they beat China at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Team_Table_Tennis_Championships" title="World Team Table Tennis Championships">World Team Table Tennis Championships</a> in Russia, breaking China's 19-year winning streak.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup> In 2021, Singapore's <a href="/wiki/Loh_Kean_Yew" title="Loh Kean Yew">Loh Kean Yew</a> achieved a "World Champion" status when he won a badminton gold at the <a href="/wiki/2021_BWF_World_Championships" title="2021 BWF World Championships">2021 BWF World Championships</a> <a href="/wiki/2021_BWF_World_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles" title="2021 BWF World Championships – Men's singles">men's singles</a>, which is one of the most prestigious badminton tournaments alongside the <a href="/wiki/Badminton_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Badminton at the Summer Olympics">Summer Olympics badminton tournaments</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore's <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> league, the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Premier_League" title="Singapore Premier League">Singapore Premier League</a>, was launched in 1996 as the S.League and comprises eight clubs, including one foreign team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[510]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[511]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Slingers" title="Singapore Slingers">Singapore Slingers</a>, formerly the Hunter Pirates in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australian_National_Basketball_League" title="Australian National Basketball League">Australian National Basketball League</a>, is one of the inaugural teams in the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Basketball_League" title="ASEAN Basketball League">ASEAN Basketball League</a>, which was founded in October 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[512]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kranji_Racecourse" title="Kranji Racecourse">Kranji Racecourse</a> is run by the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Turf_Club" title="Singapore Turf Club">Singapore Turf Club</a> and hosts several meetings per week, including international races—notably the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Airlines_International_Cup" title="Singapore Airlines International Cup">Singapore Airlines International Cup</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[513]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore began hosting a round of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formula_One_World_Championship" title="Formula One World Championship">Formula One World Championship</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Grand_Prix" title="Singapore Grand Prix">Singapore Grand Prix</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Marina_Bay_Street_Circuit" title="Marina Bay Street Circuit">Marina Bay Street Circuit</a> in 2008. It was the inaugural F1 night race,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-News_–_Singapore_confirms_2008_night_race_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-News_–_Singapore_confirms_2008_night_race-516">[514]</a></sup> and the first F1 street race in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1stStreet_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-1stStreet-517">[515]</a></sup> It is considered a signature event on the F1 calendar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Singapore" title="Media of Singapore">Media of Singapore</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Singapore" title="Telecommunications in Singapore">Telecommunications in Singapore</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2748" data-file-width="5654" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg/220px-Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg/330px-Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg/440px-Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Former-Hill-Street-Police-Station-02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Communications_and_Information" title="Ministry of Communications and Information">Ministry of Communications and Information</a> oversees the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infocomm" title="Infocomm">infocomm</a>, media and <a href="/wiki/The_arts" title="The arts">the arts</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Companies linked to the government control much of the domestic media in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_a_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse_a-519">[517]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp" title="MediaCorp">MediaCorp</a> operates most <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Singapore" title="Television in Singapore">free–to–air television channels</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Singapore" title="List of radio stations in Singapore">free–to–air radio stations</a> in Singapore. There are a total of six free–to–air TV channels offered by MediaCorp.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[518]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/StarHub_TV" title="StarHub TV">StarHub TV</a> and  <a href="/wiki/Singtel_TV" title="Singtel TV">Singtel TV</a> also offer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IPTV" title="IPTV">IPTV</a> with channels from all around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[519]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[520]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/SPH_Media_Trust" title="SPH Media Trust">SPH Media Trust</a>, a body with close links to the government, controls most of the newspaper industry in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Media_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Media-523">[521]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singapore's media industry has sometimes been criticised for being overly regulated and lacking in freedom by human rights groups such as <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_a_519-1"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse_a-519">[517]</a></sup> Self-censorship among journalists is said to be common.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Media_523-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Media-523">[521]</a></sup> In 2022, Singapore was ranked 139 on the Press Freedom Index published by <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>, up from 160 the previous year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[522]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Media_Development_Authority" title="Media Development Authority">Media Development Authority</a> regulates Singaporean media, claiming to balance the demand for choice and protection against offensive and harmful material.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mica_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mica-525">[523]</a></sup> Private ownership of TV satellite dishes is banned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Media_523-2"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Media-523">[521]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Internet_in_Singapore" title="Internet in Singapore">Internet in Singapore</a> is provided by state–owned <a href="/wiki/Singtel" title="Singtel">Singtel</a>, partially state–owned Starhub and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M1_Limited" title="M1 Limited">M1 Limited</a> as well as some other business <a href="/wiki/Internet_service_provider" title="Internet service provider">internet service providers</a> (ISPs) that offer residential service plans of speeds up to 2 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gbit/s" title="Gbit/s">Gbit/s</a> as of spring 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[524]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Equinix" title="Equinix">Equinix</a> (332 participants) and the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Internet_Exchange" title="Singapore Internet Exchange">Singapore Internet Exchange</a> (70 participants) are <a href="/wiki/Internet_exchange_point" title="Internet exchange point">Internet exchange points</a> where <a href="/wiki/Internet_service_provider" title="Internet service provider">Internet service providers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Content_delivery_network" title="Content delivery network">Content delivery networks</a> exchange Internet traffic between their networks (<a href="/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)" title="Autonomous system (Internet)">autonomous systems</a>) in various locations in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[525]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[526]</a></sup> In the mid-1980s to 1990s, Singaporeans could also use the locally based videotext service <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Teleview" title="Singapore Teleview">Singapore Teleview</a> to communicate with one another.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandfort_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-sandfort-529">[527]</a></sup> The phrase <i>Intelligent Island</i> arose in the 1990s in reference to the island nation's early adaptive relationship with the internet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandfort_529-1"><a href="#cite_note-sandfort-529">[527]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[528]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2016, there were an estimated 4.7 million internet users in Singapore, representing 82.5% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[529]</a></sup> The Singapore government does not engage in widespread censoring of the internet,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[530]</a></sup> but it maintains a list of one hundred websites—mostly pornographic—that it blocks as a "symbolic statement of the Singaporean community's stand on harmful and undesirable content on the Internet".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[531]</a></sup> As the block covers only home internet access, users may still visit the blocked websites from their office computers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[532]</a></sup> Singapore has the world's highest <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphone</a> penetration rates, in surveys by <a href="/wiki/Deloitte" title="Deloitte">Deloitte</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[533]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[534]</a></sup> and the Google Consumer Barometer — at 89% and 85% of the population respectively in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[535]</a></sup> Overall mobile phone penetration rate is at 148 mobile phone subscribers per 100 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat2014mobile_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-singstat2014mobile-538">[536]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Singapore Citizen (SC) population is 3,553,700, Permanent Resident (PR) population is 519,500, Non-Resident population is 1,563,800.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_and_Population_Structure_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-Population_and_Population_Structure-3">[3]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The break down of British Empire losses included 38,496 United Kingdom, 18,490 Australian, 67,340 Indian and 14,382 local volunteer troops. Total Australian casualties included 1,789 killed and 1,306 wounded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWigmore1957382_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWigmore1957382-58">[57]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-Population_and_Population_Structure-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Population_and_Population_Structure_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_and_Population_Structure_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.singstat.gov.sg/find-data/search-by-theme/population/population-and-population-structure/latest-data" rel="nofollow">"Population and Population Structure"</a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-IMFWEOSG-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOSG_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOSG_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOSG_5-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOSG_5-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/weo-database/2022/April" rel="nofollow">"World Economic Outlook Database, April 2022"</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBlackburnHack2004">Blackburn, Kevin; Hack, Karl (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=TUC2qveu-b8C&amp;pg=PA132" rel="nofollow"><i>Did Singapore Have to Fall?: Churchill and the Impregnable Fortress</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFGoetz1991">Goetz, Philip W. (1991). "Singapore". <i>The New Encyclopædia Britannica</i> (15th ed.). Chicago. p. 832. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1991neb..book.....G" rel="nofollow">1991neb..book.....G</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-85229-529-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-85229-529-8"><bdi>978-0-85229-529-8</bdi></a>. <q>"Singapore, known variously as the 'Lion City,' or 'Garden City,' the latter for its many parks and tree-lined streets</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Singapore&amp;rft.btitle=The+New+Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.place=Chicago&amp;rft.pages=832&amp;rft.edition=15th&amp;rft.date=1991&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1991neb..book.....G&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-85229-529-8&amp;rft.aulast=Goetz&amp;rft.aufirst=Philip+W.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFGlennieAngRhysAul2015">Glennie, Charlotte; Ang, Mavis; Rhys, Gillian; Aul, Vidhu; Walton, Nicholas (6 August 2015). <a class="external text" href="http://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/singapore-50-reasons" rel="nofollow">"50 reasons Singapore is the best city in the world"</a>. CNN<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 May</span> 2020</span>. <q>The Lion City. The Garden City. The Asian Tiger. The 'Fine' City. All venerable nicknames, and the longtime favourite is the 'Little Red Dot'</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=50+reasons+Singapore+is+the+best+city+in+the+world&amp;rft.date=2015-08-06&amp;rft.aulast=Glennie&amp;rft.aufirst=Charlotte&amp;rft.au=Ang%2C+Mavis&amp;rft.au=Rhys%2C+Gillian&amp;rft.au=Aul%2C+Vidhu&amp;rft.au=Walton%2C+Nicholas&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fedition.cnn.com%2Ftravel%2Farticle%2Fsingapore-50-reasons&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21657610-sense-vulnerability-has-made-singapore-what-it-today-can-it-now-relax-bit" rel="nofollow">"A little red dot in a sea of green"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. London. 16 July 2015. <q>..with a characteristic mixture of pride and paranoia, Singapore adopted 'little red dot' as a motto</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=A+little+red+dot+in+a+sea+of+green&amp;rft.date=2015-07-16&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnews%2Fspecial-report%2F21657610-sense-vulnerability-has-made-singapore-what-it-today-can-it-now-relax-bit&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source">"Ini kupia surat kepada Raja Barunai" [This is a copy of the letter to the Raja of Brunei]. <a class="external text" href="http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/Viewer.aspx?ref=add_ms_12398_f019r" rel="nofollow"><i>Farquhar Letterbook (Add MS 12398)</i></a> (in Malay). 1842. pp. 39–40<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-YongRao1995-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-YongRao1995_39-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMun_Cheong_YongV._V._Bhanoji_Rao1995">Mun Cheong Yong; V. <li id="cite_note-LambTarling2001-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-LambTarling2001_55-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLambTarling2001">Lamb, Margaret; Tarling, Nicholas (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4izcCwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA39" rel="nofollow"><i>From Versailles to Pearl Harbor: The Origins of the Second World War in Europe and Asia</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-yewnyt-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-yewnyt_76-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE4DD123DF931A35751C1A966958260" rel="nofollow">"Headliners; Retiring, Semi"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. 2 December 1990<span class="reference-accessdate">. Singapore: Times Academic Press.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+moment+of+anguish%3A+Singapore+in+Malaysia+and+the+politics+of+disengagement&amp;rft.place=Singapore&amp;rft.pub=Times+Academic+Press&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.aulast=Lau&amp;rft.aufirst=A&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lim2015-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Lim2015_94-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lim2015_94-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFLim2015">Lim, Edmund (22 December 2015). <a class="external text" href="https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/secret-documents-reveal-extent-of-negotiations-for-separation" rel="nofollow">"Secret documents reveal extent of negotiations for Separation"</a>. <i>The Straits Times</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-97">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/history/events/dc1efe7a-8159-40b2-9244-cdb078755013#27" rel="nofollow">"Singapore separates from Malaysia and becomes independent – Singapore History"</a>. National Library Board<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 May</span> 2017</span>. <q>Negotiations were, however, done in complete secrecy... (Tunku moved) a bill to amend the constitution that would provide for Singapore's departure from the Federation. Razak was also waiting for the fully signed separation agreement from Singapore to allay possible suggestions that Singapore was expelled from Malaysia.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Singapore+separates+from+Malaysia+and+becomes+independent+%E2%80%93+Singapore+History&amp;rft.pub=National+Library+Board&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feresources.nlb.gov.sg%2Fhistory%2Fevents%2Fdc1efe7a-8159-40b2-9244-cdb078755013%2327&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://eservice.nlb.gov.sg/item_holding_s.aspx?bid=12751459" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Singapore</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-149"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-149">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFOrtmannThompson2016">Ortmann, Stephan; Thompson, Mark R (January 2016). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161104151140/http://www.journalofdemocracy.org/sites/default/files/Thompson-27-1.pdf" rel="nofollow">"China and the 'Singapore Model'<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Journal of Democracy</i>. <b>27</b> (1): 39–48. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1353%2Fjod.2016.0004" rel="nofollow">10.1353/jod.2016.0004</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:155860923" rel="nofollow">155860923</a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-150"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-150">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHuff1995">Huff, W G (1995). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110214102853/http://cje.oxfordjournals.org/content/19/6/735.full.pdf+html" rel="nofollow">"What is the Singapore model of economic development?"</a>. <i>Cambridge Journal of Economics</i>. <b>19</b>: 735–759. <li id="cite_note-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-239">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071005194408/http://www.nbrcnparks.org/initiatives_nation.asp" rel="nofollow">"National Initiatives"</a>. Singapore. Agence France-Presse. 26 September 2007. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">22 April</span> 2010</span>. <q>For the second year running, Singapore tops the aggregate rankings on the ease of doing business in 2006 to 2007.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=AsiaOne&amp;rft.atitle=Singapore+top+paradise+for+business%3A+World+Bank&amp;rft.date=2007-09-26&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbusiness.asiaone.com%2FBusiness%2FNews%2FSME%252BCentral%2FStory%2FA1Story20070926-27084.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-273">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.xe.com/ucc/convert/?Amount=1&amp;From=USD&amp;To=SGD" rel="nofollow">"Based on USD/SGD rate of 1.221"</a>. <li id="cite_note-347"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-347">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100401014335/http://www.lta.gov.sg/corp_info/doc/Average_Daily_Public_Transport_Ridership.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Public transport ridership"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Land Transport Authority. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.lta.gov.sg/corp_info/doc/Average_Daily_Public_Transport_Ridership.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 1 April 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-459"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-459">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRamesh2008">Ramesh, M. <li id="cite_note-475"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-475">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060524013952/http://www.mica.gov.sg/renaissance/FinalRen.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Culture and the Arts in Renaissance Singapore"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Information,_Communications_and_the_Arts" title="Ministry of Information, Communications and the Arts">Ministry of Information, Communications and the Arts</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.mica.gov.sg/renaissance/FinalRen.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 24 May 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-streetfood-492"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-streetfood_492-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-streetfood_492-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFMichaels2013">Michaels, Rowena (20 July 2013). <span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a class="external text" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/expat/expatlife/10204790/Singapores-best-street-food-...-just-dont-order-frog-porridge.html" rel="nofollow">"Singapore's best street food ... just don't order frog porridge"</a></span>. <i>The Daily Telegraph</i>. London. <a class="external text" href="https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/expat/expatlife/10204790/Singapores-best-street-food-...-just-dont-order-frog-porridge.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 10 January 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">.
